t: Job 13
Job Says His Friends’ Proverbs Are Ashes
“Behold,*pn my eye has seen all this,*i My*ln ear has heard and understood it.
What*ln you know I also know; I*ln am not inferior to you.
“But*ln I would speak to the Almighty, And*ln I desire to argue with God.
But*ln you smear with lies; You*ln are all worthless physicians.
O*ln that you would be completely silent, And*ln that it would become your wisdom!
Please*ln hear my argument And*ln listen to the contentions of my lips.
Will*ln you speak what is unjust for God, And*ln speak what is deceitful for Him?
Will*ln you show partiality for Him? Will*ln you contend for God?
Will*ln it be well when He examines you? Or*ln will you deceive Him as one deceives a man?
He*ln will surely reprove you If*ln you secretly show partiality.
Will*ln not His majesty terrify you, And*ln the dread of Him fall on you?
Your*ln memorable sayings are proverbs of ashes, Your*ln defenses are defenses of clay.
Job Is Sure He Will Be Vindicated
“Be*pn silent before me so that I may speak; Then*ln let come on me what may.
Why*ln should I take my flesh in my teeth And*ln put my life in my hands?
Though*ln He slay me, I*ln will hope in Him. Nevertheless*ln I will argue my ways before Him.
This*ln also will be my salvation, For*ln a godless man may not come before His presence.
Listen*ln carefully to my speech, And*ln let my declaration fill*i your ears.
Behold*ln now, I have prepared my case; I*ln know that I will be vindicated.
Who*ln will contend with me? For*ln then I would be silent and die.
“Only*ln two things do not do to me, Then*ln I will not hide from Your face:
Remove*ln Your hand from me, And*ln let not the dread of You terrify me.
Then*ln call, and I will answer; Or*ln let me speak, then reply to me.
How*ln many are my iniquities and sins? Make*ln known to me my rebellion and my sin.
Why*ln do You hide Your face And*ln consider me Your enemy?
Will*ln You cause a driven leaf to tremble? Or*ln will You pursue the dry chaff?
For*ln You write bitter things against me And*ln make me to inherit the iniquities of my youth.
You*ln put my feet in the stocks And*ln watch all my paths; You*ln set a limit for the soles of my feet,
While*ln I am decaying like a rotten thing, Like*ln a garment that is moth-eaten.
